source.name: Abstraction2
source.instructions: The sub problems of a deconstructed problem are guaranteed to be easy to solve.

parts of the
problem.

Simulations can help predict future events.

source.name: Representation4
source.instructions:
A compression method finds multiple letters in a row and converts them to a number-letter pair.  For example the word GOOD would become G20D to show that there are two Os in a row.  This method only makes the text smaller if there are three or more of the same letter in a row.  B7O would be BOOOOOOO.

source.name: Storage1
source.instructions: A file on your computer desktop is most likely saved:

answers.answer: In the cloud... a datacenter somewhere in the world.

answers.answer: In a computer, disconnected from the network.

source.instructions: Embedded Systems are in many everyday devices.

source.name: Embedded2
source.instructions: Modern "smart" appliances rely on an embedded system to communicate.

source.instructions: Word bank: Voltage, LEDs.
source.text: Dimmable LED light blubs work by turning off some of the LEDs that are in a cluster as the voltage drops.  In this scenario an embedded micro controller is responding to the <<<voltage>>> as an input and using the <<<LEDs>>> as an output.

source.name: Embedded4
source.instructions: Security is a concern with embedded systems.  If a system is connected to the Internet, it could be hacked.  Which of the following are embedded systems that could (theoretically) be hacked by someone across the Internet?

answers.answer: A camera that allows you to check in on your home while away
A coffee maker that has an embedded timer to brew coffee at the same time each day.
A thermostat that learns as you use it and gives you a weekly summary of your energy usage to your phone.
A voice activated assistant that can tell you the weather, or other information.
An automatic pet feeder that releases food at a set time throughout the day.
A fitness band that tracks your steps and activity throughout the day and allowing you to compete against friends for "most active" bragging rights.

source.name: Data1
source.instructions: The term "big data" refers to

answers.answer: Very large numbers used in cryptography.
Many individual data points gathered across thousands or millions of people.
Data processing by computers to find patterns that could not be found by hand.
Large files that cannot fit onto one computer's hard drive.
Large datasets about everything from individual shopping habits to decades of climate data all of which can be analyzed for patterns and trends at some later point.

source.name: Data2
source.instructions: Data profiles are used to make predictions about individuals.  These profiles are made by:

answers.answer: Comparing your online habits with thousands of other similar people and using their choices to predict your future choices.
Building a detailed profile and model of you as an individual and running simulations on what you might do in different situations.
Asking friends and family which of several options you would like.
Showing the same advertisement to everyone hoping that some people will find it interesting.

source.name: Data3
source.instructions: Metadata is:

answers.answer: All the data about given communication including the message.
Data that has already been analysed to find trends or patterns.
Data about data like the time and duration of a phone call.
Data that cannot be analysed or is useless.

source.name: Data4
source.instructions: Public data sets can be accessed for use and analysis.  The way to access this data is:

answers.answer: Accessing the data through the public API.
Placing a "request for analysis" to a certified data scientist.

source.name: Real1

source.name: Real3
source.instructions: Disease transmission can be difficult to predict.  By running simulations, we can perfectly predict where a disease will spread.
